results.title: On guard for thee. Part 1. The Most dangerous spy
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, James Littleton, Roger Hart, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The first in a trilogy of one-hour films on Canada’s national security operations and civil liberties during the past half-century. In 1946, Igor Gouzenko, a Soviet cipher clerk in Ottawa, fled his embassy with documents unveiling his nation’s spy network in Canada. It was Canada’s first spy case and confusion reigned in official reaction. Counter-intelligence agencies in the United States and Britain became alarmed at the possible leak of the new atom bomb secrets, so man-hunts soon reached international proportions. In Canada, the government ordered the arrest of many suspected citizens, civil rights were suspended, and the ensuing events became a blot on the nation’s history.

results.title: On call to a nation
results.creator_credit: Richard Cawston and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A review, consisting of many interviews with doctors of the British National Health Service ten years after it was started. Country and city general practitioners, specialists, public health doctors and hospital personnel discuss the failures and successes of the scheme, the emergence of partnerhsips, group practices and health centres, the shortage of dentists, and the growing gap between specialists and general practitioners, hospital deficiencies and the difficulties of the coutry practitioner with a small scattered population.

results.title: Ombudsman
results.brief_description: For 160 years Sweden has had Ombudsmen to whom the public can appeal directly in breaches of civil liberties, abuse of authority or any other apparent injustice. Explains the function of the Ombudsmen, through the reconstruction of typical cases where their independent investigations have resulted in the correction of injustices.

results.title: Oman today: the challenge
results.brief_description: Since the early seventies Oman has been involved in a development process that began with the opening of the country to the modern world. The role of UNICEF and other agencies, as well as specialists from other Arab countries is outlined.

results.title: Olympic wrestling: an introduction
results.brief_description: Part one: Provides a history of wrestling, its suitability for schools, and a description of training programmmes for developing skills. Part two: Explains the rules of a match, the roles of the officials and the scoring system. No other credits available.

results.title: Olympic torch relay: living the dream
results.creator_credit: Erica Powell, Michael McCarthy, Paul Mullan, Trevor Seaman, Black Magic Media and SOCOG
results.brief_description: On May 10, 2000 in Olympia, Greece, the Olympic Flame burst into life for the Sydney 2000 Olympics. This video follows the path of the torch from Greece to Guam, where it began a two week journey through 13 Pacific Island countries of Oceania. Then, onto its 100 day, 27,000 km tour of Australia, beginning with the arrival at Connellan Airport at Yulara, Northern Territory on 8 June, 2000. The relay concluded with the lighting of the cauldron at the Sydney Olympic Games Opening Ceremony, 15 September 2000. The purpose of the torch relay was to spread the spirit of the Olympic Games to as many Australians as possible and as a commemorative tribute, the names of each of the 11,000 Torchbearers and 2,500 escort runners are listed at the end of the video.

results.title: Olympic swimmers
results.creator_credit: Gilles Carle, Jacques Bobet and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Shows Canada’s top swimmers in training for the 1964 Olympic Games. In gymnasium and pool, under the critical eye of coach Ed Healy, they practise long hours to build strength and stamina. Their first test, shown in the film, was at the 1962 Canadian Swimming Championships, at which they carried off a number of trophies.
